questions.question:
Question 1: A 50-year-old male was rushed to the ER with complaints of chest pain for the past 45 
minutes and was started on isosorbide mononitrate. How does this drug act?
questions.explanation:
Nitrates like isosorbide mononitrate act by increasing the concentration of the second messenger 
cGMP. They are used to relieve angina and cause vasodilation. 164 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following drugs is not used in angina?
questions.explanation:
Sacubitril is not used in angina. Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor, approved for use in the 
treatment of heart failure.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to 
have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case?

options.c: Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume

questions.explanation:
The mechanism of action of nitrates in prinzmetal angina is endothelium-independent coronary 
vasodilatation. Prinzmetal angina occurs due to vasospasm of the coronary arteries. Nitrates relax the smooth 
muscles of epicardial coronary arteries and relieve coronary artery spasm. In the case of stable angina, the primary mechanism of action of nitrates is preferential dilatation 
of veins (by increasing cGMP). Venous dilatation leads to a decrease in the venous return to the 
heart (preload). This decreases the ventricular end-diastolic volume and thereby a decrease in 
myocardial oxygen consumption. The diastolic perfusion pressure (aortic blood pressure in 
diastole - left ventricular pressure in diastole) is increased.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 45-year-old patient who suffers from prinzmetal angina requires a formulation of 
nitroglycerine which has the most rapid onset of action. Which of the following formulations 
of nitroglycerin can be administered to the patient? 158 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The sublingual route of administration has a very rapid onset of action (1-3 mins). The onset of 
action is more rapid when administered as a spray when compared to a tablet. The sublingual route is used for the termination of attacks. Oral extended-release capsule and 
transdermal patch are used for prophylaxis. The onset of action is approximately 60 min. 165 
Sold by @itachibot Topical nitroglycerine ointment can be used to provide symptomatic relief in patients with anal 
fissures.

questions.question:
Question 5: In patients with angina, nitroglycerine should not be administered by which of the following 
routes?
questions.explanation:
Intramuscular nitroglycerin should be avoided due to severe pain in the injection area in patients 
with angina. Sublingual and intravenous nitroglycerin can be used for acute effects. Oral extended-release 
capsules are available for prophylactic use in angina.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 30-year-old man suspected to have cyanide poisoning is brought to the ER. The medical 
officer stabilizes the patient and asks the nurse to bring an ampoule of amyl nitrite. By which 
of the following routes is this drug administered?
questions.explanation:
Amyl nitrite is administered via the inhalational route for acute relief in angina and cyanide 
poisoning. Amyl nitrite is a highly volatile liquid available in glass ampoules. Its unpleasant odor and very 
short duration of action have made its use obsolete in angina.

questions.question:
Question 7: An 18-year-old boy was brought to the ER in an unconscious state. His coworker states he 
works in a factory manufacturing pesticides. Based on this, the medical officer suspects 
cyanide poisoning and administers sodium nitrite. Which of the following is the mechanism 
of action of this drug in this case?
questions.explanation:
The mechanism of action of sodium nitrite as an antidote for cyanide poisoning is by the 
development of methemoglobinemia. Cyanide binds to the cytochrome oxidase (complex IV) of the electron transport chain (ETC), 
thereby blocking it. When sodium nitrite is administered, it releases the nitrite ion. This ion binds 
to hemoglobin to form methemoglobin. The methemoglobin so formed, has a high affinity for the 
cyanide ion and binds to it, thus, detaching it from the cytochrome oxidase. This regenerates 
active cytochrome normalizing the function of ETC. The cyanide ion with methemoglobin forms cyanmethemoglobin. Sodium thiosulphate is 
administered for the elimination of this compound. The thiosulfate forms thiocyanate ion with 
the cyanide and this is readily excreted.

questions.question:
Question 8: A middle-aged man came to the casualty with complaints of abdominal pain. On examination, 
it is noted that the pain radiates from the loin to the groin of the patient. The resident wants 
to administer a drug to the patient for symptomatic relief. Which drug is not effective in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
Abdominal pain radiating from loin to groin is suggestive of renal colic. Nitrates are not effective 
in renal colic. In renal colic, NSAIDs, and morphine are used for acute pain relief. Due to the short time of 
action of nitrates, their clinical efficacy as relaxants in genitourinary system is quite low. Therapeutic Uses of nitrates are: • Angina pectoris 166 
Sold by @itachibot • Acute coronary syndrome • Myocardial infarction • CHF • Biliary colic • Esophageal spasm

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient who is on treatment for angina, presents to you with erectile dysfunction. You 
decide against prescribing sildenafil because the patient is being treated with
questions.explanation:
The patient would be on nitrates for angina and thus should not be prescribed sildenafil as 
sildenafil causes dangerous potentiation of nitrate action resulting in severe hypotension. The combination of the two drugs has a synergistic action on the intracellular cGMP levels that 
can result in uninhibited vasodilation and a precipitous fall in blood pressure. Hence, the use of 
sildenafil is a contraindication when on nitrates.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 30-year-old male, who works in a factory that manufactures explosives, came to the OPD 
with a peculiar complaint. He says that he gets headaches and feels transient dizziness every 
Monday after his weekend off. Exposure to which compound is likely to produce his 
symptoms?
questions.explanation:
The patient is most likely suffering from Monday disease which is associated with exposure 
to nitroglycerin. Continuous exposure to high levels of nitrates can occur in the chemical industry, especially where 
explosives are manufactured. When contamination of the workplace with nitrate compounds is severe, workers find that upon 
starting their week, they suffer headaches and transient dizziness. After a day or so back at work, 
tolerance develops. Over the weekend, when exposure to the chemicals is reduced, tolerance 
disappears, so symptoms recur each Monday.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 60 year old male is on verapamil for angina. Which of the following is not an adverse effect 
of this medication? 160 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Tachycardia is not an adverse effect of verapamil. Verapamil has a direct negative chronotropic effect on the heart. It is more likely to cause 
bradycardia because of its significant cardio depressant action. Any reflex stimulation of heart due 
to peripheral vasodilation is effectively countered by the direct effect. Common side effects of verapamil include headache, gingival hyperplasia, and constipation.

questions.question:
Question 12: Nifedipine acts by blocking  
calcium channels.
questions.explanation:
Nifedipine acts by blocking L-type calcium channels. 167 
Sold by @itachibot Verapamil, diltiazem, and dihydropyridines block L-type calcium channels by binding to alpha 1 
subunit. Verapamil was the first clinically used calcium channel blocker.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which among the following is a newer dihydropyridine with additional N-type calcium 
channel blocking activity?
questions.explanation:
Cilnidipine is a novel dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that blocks both L- and N-type 
calcium channels. Blockage of N-type calcium channels results in the reduction of sympathetic activity. It provides 
additional anti-hypertensive action without inducing reflex tachycardia.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is more likely to precipitate angina?
questions.explanation:
Amongst the given calcium channel blockers, nifedipine is more likely to precipitate angina. Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker having a rapid onset and short duration 
of action. It results in an abrupt decrease in blood pressure resulting in reflex tachycardia. 
Increased contractility leads to an increase in O2 demand which may precipitate angina. Option A: Amlodipine and extended-release preparations of nifedipine do not cause a steep fall in 
blood pressure and subsequent activation of sympathetic tone. Therefore, they are less likely to 
precipitate angina. Options C and D: Verapamil and diltiazem have relatively less action on peripheral vascular 
smooth muscles. They have a direct inhibitory effect on cardiac tissue causing negative ionotropic 
effect (verapamil > diltiazem).

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient with polycystic kidney disease came to the ER with complaints of severe headache. 
An NCCT brain was taken and it showed subarachnoid hemorrhage. Which of the following 161 
Sold by @itachibot drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Nimodipine is the most appropriate drug that can be given to this patient. Nimodipine is indicated in cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage. It has a high 
affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce mortality after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.question:
Question 16: Peripheral edema seen with the use of calcium channel blockers is primarily due to which of 
the following mechanisms?

options.a: Reduced glomerular filtration rate and renal blood flow
options.b: Increased hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries of lower extremeties
options.c: Decreased oncotic pressure due to loss of plasma proteins in urine
options.d: Precapillary constriction and post capillary dilation

questions.explanation:
Calcium channel blockers induced peripheral edema is most likely due to increased hydrostatic 
pressure in the capillaries of the lower extremities. The increased hydrostatic pressure occurs due to precapillary dilation and reflex postcapillary 
constriction. 168 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: A 30-year-old athlete complained of chest pain during his practice sessions. He is diagnosed 
to be suffering from exertional angina and is prescribed atenolol. Which of the following 
changes are not caused by this drug?
questions.explanation:
Atenolol is a beta-blocker which increases the coronary collateral circulation, thereby increasing 
the blood flow towards the ischaemic region. This provides relief in exertional angina. Beta-blockers decrease the heart rate, contractility, and arterial blood pressure. These effects are 
beneficial by decreasing the myocardial O2 demand. A decrease in heart rate increases the time 
available for myocardial perfusion.

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following drugs can be used to balance the undesirable effects of beta-blockers 
in angina?
questions.explanation:
Beta-blockers cause an increase in end-diastolic volume and ejection time. These effects can be 
balanced using nitrates by preferential venous dilatation, thus reducing preload. Beta-blockers also block the baroreceptor mediated reflex tachycardia caused by nitrates due to 
vasodilation. Options A and D: Verapamil and diltiazem are not combined with beta-blockers as they can cause 
additive suppression of SA node and AV nodal conduction. Option C: Ivabradine is a pacemaker I(f) "funny" current inhibitor. Its addition does not reverse 
the undesirable effect but only adds to the bradycardia caused by beta blockers.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following drugs is associated with coronary steal phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Coronary steal phenomenon is seen with dipyridamole. In patients with partial obstruction of coronary vasculature, a region of ischemia develops in the 
myocardium. In the absence of drugs, arterioles in the ischemic areas are usually maximally 
dilated as a result of local compensatory mechanisms. When dipyridamole is administered, it acts as a nonselective arteriolar dilator. It can only dilate 
the vessels of the normal myocardium as the vessels of the ischemic myocardium are already 
maximally dilated. This diverts (steals) the blood away from the ischemic myocardium towards 
the normal myocardium. This is termed as coronary steal phenomenon.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements about ranolazine is not true?

options.a: It is recommended as first-line treatment for acute angina.

questions.explanation:
Ranolazine is not recommended as a first-line agent for acute angina. It is approved as a 
second-line agent for chronic angina. Ranolazine acts by reducing late sodium current (INa) that facilitates calcium entry via the 
sodium-calcium exchanger. The reduction in intracellular calcium concentration results in 
decreased cardiac contractility. Additionally, it also reduces cardiac fatty acid oxidation and 
stimulates glucose metabolism. It results in a small decrease in HBA1c, thus improving glycemic 
control. 169 
Sold by @itachibot It is metabolized by CYP3A4 and hence should not be used with CYP3A4 inhibitors such as 
macrolides, imidazole antibiotics, and HIV protease inhibitors. The most frequent side effects are dizziness, headache, nausea, and constipation. Hypotension is 
uncommon.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is a rho-kinase inhibitor?
questions.explanation:
Fasudil is a selective RhoA /rho-kinase inhibitor. The Rho kinases (ROC•) are a family of enzymes that inhibit vascular relaxation. Their excessive 
activity has been noted in coronary spasm and pulmonary hypertension. Inhibiton of these 
enzymes results in vascular relaxation. Option B: Ranolazine acts by reducing late sodium current (INa). This reduces calcium entry via 
the sodium-calcium exchanger. Option C: Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidation (pFO™) inhibitor. Option D: Nicorandil is an agonist of •ATP channels

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following drugs causes activation of •+-ATP channels?
questions.explanation:
Nicorandil causes activation of •+-ATP channels. This leads to the hyperpolarization of the 
smooth muscle cells leading to vasodilatation. It also has nitrate like cGMP dependent action. Nicorandil dilates both arteries and veins leading 
to a decrease in afterload and preload of the heart. Molsidomine, isosorbide dinitrate, and nitroglycerin are nitrates. They do not act on •-ATP 
channels. 170 
Sold by @itachibot Heart Failure Drugs
